Posts.Content: I've not examined all of the claims about breast cancer and alcohol. Personally I don't take much interest in what an article in a magazine or newspaper would say on any given health issue and instead I look for published research that would give me a better picture. Since my own diagnosis I've simply not had the time to read the most recent published papers on risk factors and see the strength of relevance for any given factor. Hopefully in the future I will get a chance to do this. That aside, I'm not surprised that your sister starting drinking heavily after her BC diagnosis. It would have been a huge shock. I've had family members who had previously given up smoking start again when faced with terrible life events. Your sister is facing several whammy's of horribleness. First of all she has breast cancer, then she starts drinking again after being sober for month, then she faces chemo (something I never want to ever do again), then she has the extra potential "blame" on top that her drinking has lead her to the breast cancer and so on. She may be beating herself up and dealing with it through drinking.  Chemo was so bad for me I'd easily have lapsed into previous bad behaviour.  If drinking would have made me feel better I would have welcomed it.  I can only imagine the damage being done through all these chemo drugs and alcohol to her liver. My liver hasn't recovered and I'm 6 months past chemo. The focus right now needs to be helping her to survive chemo and cancer maybe? I was hospitalised on my chemo cycles with infections until I refused to go near them again. I didn't take my medicine as I discovered that some of the drugs were making my symptoms worse (i.e. dizzyness, weakness) and my consultant insisted I take a steroid for one cycle that I had previous reacted badly to. My advice would be to give your support to your sister for her chemo treatment and see if anything could be done to help her get through this without any blame for either her current drinking or the idea that her drinking led to the breast cancer. Have you taken any advice from her doctors as to the effect her current drinking is having on the effectiveness of her chemo drugs to shrink or eradicate the cancer?  If so, are there alternative cancer treatments available to her that could cope with her possible non-compliance to chemo? Then when she has got through chemo and survived her breast cancer offer to fund any treatment of choice for her addiction that she chooses. Just a few ideas. Hope this ramble is of some help to you and your sister.

Chemo as you know wipes out white blood cells. I have a neurological disease and the same effect (i.e. the disease going into remission) is also being reported with some chemos. Posts.Content: Hi Anstri, One of the tenants of the NHS is that patients must give an informed consent on any treatment. You shouldn't be railroaded into anything that you don't understand and all the risks and alternatives should be explained to you. The final choice should be yours. For me, reading your post, the big question is why chemo before surgery is out? It may be that they ran tests on the past biopsies and determined that this wouldn't work.  This is something you should be told though.  You can't in practice agree to a mastectomy without knowing why you can't get a lumpectomy. The size of the tumour isn't enough of a reason in all cases. My experience was that I had a large and fast growing tumour in a hard to get to place - and all on small breasts. Biopsies of my lymph nodes during my initial examinations showed cancer. We agreed on chemo to shrink the lump, then to try for a lumpectomy. This worked well for me and during the operation I asked them to biopsy my lymph nodes again instead of removing them. There was no cancer and my lump had shrunk to barely nothing. That was my decision which I determined after considering the alternatives. The downside was that the chemo was so grueling I am still trying to recover as the side effects were for me, long and severe. Some people, my Oncologist said, wanted an operation before chemo. They would rather have the lump removed even if that means a mastectomy rather than waiting to see if a lumpectomy is possible. For some people it's just not an alternative though. None of us know what the future will bring when cancer treatment starts. Any of the procedures we have could bring minor or major problems. That's why we need to give our informed consent to this. Once something is done we can't look back in regret and wish it undone. There shouldn't be any surprises we don't know about. However, with cancer treatment doctors need to use a process to give the alternatives to us. They do however, have an obligation to explain this.  I found with treatment that the decisions went on and on. When I started chemo I didn't know for 8 months if it would work and shrink the lump. Then I didn't know if the cancer was still in my lymph nodes. Some women go through all of this, then they still need a mastectomy. It should be our choice though. My breast cancer nurse was useless but you may have a good one. My Oncologist's secretary was also useful. When I had surgery I went back and spoke it through twice before I consented to the operation. Some patients don't want to be closely involved with decisions. I have a friend going though treatment now who doesn't want to read about it or question her doctors. I found the whole process overwhelming and there was a long and continual learning curve. Posts.Content: Hi 4PAWS, Sometimes we need to complain loudly to be heard. It shouldn't be like this but some clinics have crap individual staff members and it sounds as if you have met one of these.  My experience was dire. Had vomiting and nausea all through FEC and when I started Doxetacel my Oncologist claimed that this was stop. Of course it didn't. I couldn't even get through the first infusion. The staff were hopeless and my breast care nurse "didn't do chemo". Later when I looked it up Doxetaxel was lower in the % of sickness side effects but it was still there for some people (maybe 10%?) There is no reason why you should be left to suffer like this. There are at least 6 different physical pathways in the body to try and control nausea and vomiting. You may need drugs from more than one area to get this under control. I ended up on around 4 to make a dent in the problem. What I had to do was complain loudly and then again. I spoke to PALS at the hospital and said I needed help. I also rang my Oncologist's Secretary and asked for help urgently. I rang my GP. This sounds like it was easy but given that the side effects were so severe that I couldn't lift my head from the pillow, in all took weeks to do. For the pain I came across an old medical paper on anti-histamines and pain in chemo. I added Claritine and Benedryl to the drugs I was taking. If you can get it the COx2 inhibitor Celebrex helped me. If you can't get to talk to anyone tonight is there an emergency number for your clinic (mine had a bleeper) or can you call out your GP?  In my case the motion sickness drug Cyclizine was the first that made a small difference and I was able to buy some from Boots. I've never had motion sickness before (was a good sailor) but now get it even in a car.  You may find that you need a completely different combo of drugs. One of the drugs I was given metoclopramide was a disaster and had it's own set of side effects.  With the horrible taste in my mouth I found citrus was a friend. Freshly squeezed OJ, squirt of lemon in water and ginger drinks if I could tolerate them.  I drank milky drinks from the supermarket (i.e. chocolate or banana mllk) which was bizarre as I hate them normally. Fruit smoothies - sometimes the tart ones and sometime sweet like strawberry. Couldn't tolerate pineapple but yes to fresh grapes. With regards to the high temperature is there any chance it could be an infection? I was told to get to A&E and given a card to show them at the first sign of a high temp. I ended up with infections on all three of my FEC's. Good luck!

I can't work, drive a car or leave my home for other than short appointments. I've been quite calm about this. Apparently I am returning to my old self and am able to exercise (something she wants me to do). Nothing could be further from the truth. It would be a miracle if I could exercise (as it is causing severe symptoms if I do) and this is very damaging misinformation that is now on my medical file.  Everything came crashing down on me when I saw that letter. After the appointment with her that day I had been so weak I could only crawl on my hands and knees up the stairs to my home. Then  I came down with a bad flu and a sinus infection. My immunity appears to be very low. What I did was to make an appointment to see someone at my local MacMillan centre  (when I could move again) as emotionally and physically I felt devastated. Posts.Content: Really sorry to hear what a bad time you are having with Chemo. I found both the FEC - T chemo regime I was on very hard with many side effects and different infections/outbreaks. I wonder if your case is similar to the one reported in the following link at all?  Paclitaxel-Induced Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis www.ajronline.org/.../ajr.176.3.1760718 As you had the coughing reaction straight away on the second Paclitaxel could your reaction be a hypersensitivity Pneumonitis? The patient in that article was switched to Doxetaxal and given anti-histamines and steroids  before the infusion. They also tested for the normal bugs that cause typical pneumonitis but found none. Xrays looked like normal pneumonia. "" (quote from link) Because of the risk of a recurrent hypersensitivity reaction, the patient was not re-challenged with paclitaxel and instead was switched to another taxoid, doxetaxel (Taxotere; Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, Collegeville, PA), that is believed to be less allergenic. Administered in conjunction with a premedication regimen consisting of steroids and histamine1 and histamine2 antagonists, five cycles of doxetaxel were tolerated by the patient without complications. "" It may be that you need to switch to another drug and then add the different anti-histamines as they did for the patient there. The steroid used could be important for some people. I'm very allergic and cannot tolerate Dexamethasone. Bad reactions to that in the past from doctors treating allergies. It needs to be Predislone for me.  Might be the complete opposite for you. We just don't know. Hopefully your doctors can work this one out.

Posts.Content: I found learning about breast cancer a hard learning curve. My experience was that I had a painful lump and swollen sore glands leading down to the lump. When I had the examination in the breast care clinic they took a couple of biopsies of my glands at the same time. I was able to learn from this that the cancer had spread my my glands. It was probably my presenting symptoms (the swollen sore glands right up to my jaw) that made them do the biopsy then and there. The next step was to see if it had spread further. That was done by a CT scan. However, this took time and I started chemo before we had the results. It was clear. It's quite possible that the cancer has spread and your Mother had no symptoms. On the other hand it may be no immediate danger and quite treatable.  No way to know sadly. Even if the cancer has spread to her lymph nodes it may have got no further. The cancer I had was really well controlled by the chemo. My lump disappeared to almost nothing and the cancer in my lymph nodes disappeared. They did another biopsy when I had my lumpectomy.  My Mother had lung cancer that didn't grow fast and remained stable for a long. Sorry not to be able to give any more advice. It's wait and see sorry. Just make sure that they do the testing needed quickly and report back. Don't be frightened of asking questions or pushing them. Mine took a long time. They were hopeless of about feeding back results to me.

Posts.Content: No you are not going mad. There is a high level of denial in the medical profession in my experience of the severity and variety of side effects from chemo drugs. I've been quite lucky in that a GP I saw did not discount experience. There have been attempts all through my treatment to either subtly or actively deny my experience. This has come from everyone involved in my direct chemo care with a few exceptions. At the end of the day I wonder how much they can do to help and if that drives this deliberate ignorance. I've been meaning to sit down and look at the actual published medical literature and see what quality research has been carried out on treating side effects. As I discovered when I was so sick on FEC-T there was a lot more that they could have done to help me but didn't. The technique that they are using is called "gas lighting" to try and get you to shut up.  en.wikipedia.org/.../Gaslighting Our doctors want us to finish the course and for some of them sticking their head in the ground and not admitting just how hard that is works.  It sounds like you just want someone to validate what you are going through. It would also be good if they could do something to help. What I have done is to just not take any nonsense and declare a zero tolerance of BS from them. This is very hard to do when one is weak, sick, dizzy and has chemo-brain. The more of us who are fobbed us the less likely it is for side effects to ever be acknowledged in cancer treatment. The next thing that they will probably start doing as we (as a group) become better informed and less tolerant to listen to them is accuse us of looking at the side effects list and then being influenced. I didn't look at any info on side effects before I go them but that didn't stop them trying this on... Here's a list of side effects. You will see insomnia, dizzyness listed. Print this off and mark the ones you have then sent to to an idiot who argues with you.  http://www.nhs.uk/conditions/Herceptin/Pages/Introduction.aspx I think that I have had my last Herceptin shot but I won't know until late August as they need to do an audit. Someone made a mistake in my log book. Towards the end of Herceptin I nearly had to insist on a break as I could feel the FEC-T side effects slow and the Herceptin ones start getting worse. In the end I stuck it out but as I did with the FEC-T I ended up on a 4 weekly rather than a 3 weekly cycle. I was going to ask for that with Herceptin.

I'm prone (with out chemo) to recurring bouts of herpes simplex (manifests as cold sores) and shingles. For my time on chemo my doctor has added Valtrex (I don't do well on Acyclovir) for the duration. During my first cycle of FEC I got a outbreak of sores/blisters all over my face and my doctor thought it was one of the herpes viri. Valtrex cleared it up and has kept it at bay. I realise that I had bacterial infections then but I am hoping that they are also good for viral ones? Just a few ideas. The chemo team may be willing to give you something as a prophylactic and they will know better.

Posts.Content: Hi Cocopops, Yes, it could get worse and T could be even worse after that. I'm talking from my own experience only and not intending to frighten or upset you.  I ended up bed-bound and very sick / weak/ fainting /falling and confused from FEC and the drugs that my clinic gave me. Couldn't log onto to ask for help and advice in that first horrible cycle. Never recovered from FEC each month, it was cumulative and then Taxotore added it's own devastation. What I did was to take control and stop my Chemo team from doing further damage. This is what helped for me but I know we are all different so these are just ideas (just as an aside I am now about 3 plus months post chemo and not recovered as yet). These hints are intended for emergencies and people who genuinely don't think that can make it through. 1. Get the dose of FEC reduced if possible to the smallest therapeutic dose. In my case this worked well in that it shrank the tumour very well.  2. Change from a 3 weekly cycle to a 4 weekly cycle if not recovering or of side effects are too severe. 3. Don't be lulled into thinking that Tax will be significantly better. It was certainly different for me and probably better than FEC but had it's own. I got my team to cut the Tax dose down to the smallest amount possible to start with and I am so glad I did this. 4. Consider the idea you may be having a reaction not only to the Chemo meds but the other drugs as well. Look closely at any other meds they give you either as part of the infusion or after. I am thinking of steroids and anti-sickness meds. I had severe nausea and vomiting with both FEC and Tax. Some of the drugs they were giving me were not only having no effect on that symptom but making my fainting/ disorientation and weakness much worse. As an example I told them that I had reacted badly to Dexamethosone before but they insisted I take it for the sickness and vomiting. That was really bad advice. I got them to change this to Predislone. The other drug making me weak and dizzy was the anti-sickness drug Metoclopramide. This is under the side effects of Metoclopramide (only using this as an example). My clinic gives anti-sickness meds as part of the chemo infusion regime as well and they didn't tell me or give me any notification or a pamphlet on side effects "Stop taking metoclopramide and call your doctor at once if you have any of these other serious side effects: slow or jerky muscle movements, problems with balance or walking; mask-like appearance in your face; very stiff (rigid) muscles, high fever, sweating, confusion, fast or uneven heartbeats, tremors, feeling like you might pass out; depressed mood, thoughts of suicide or hurting yourself; hallucinations, anxiety, agitation, jittery feeling, trouble staying still; swelling, feeling short of breath, rapid weight gain; jaundice (yellowing of your skin or eyes); or seizure (convulsions). Less serious metoclopramide side effects may include: feeling restless, drowsy, tired, or dizzy; headache, sleep problems (insomnia); nausea, vomiting, diarrhea; breast tenderness or swelling; changes in your menstrual periods; or urinating more than usual." 5. Ask you team for alternatives. FEC-T isn't the only regime. There are alternatives. As said these ideas are mentioned specifically for people getting side effects from Chemo and associated drugs that could possibly be avoided and to help make it possible for them to complete a course. I was lucky. FEC-T (even modified as I did) worked for me. It shrunk the lump and I was able to have a lumpectomy. It's not going to be the case for everyone though. The best people to talk to are your team but my experience was that they were useless initially and I had to be firm and insistent before they would listen.  That's hard to do when Chemo disables our minds and bodies.  Hope it helps.

Posts.Content: Hi Rox, My feeling is that you are entering one of these NHS "Black holes" of knowledge and experience. That was what happened to me anyway. I have a neurological disease plus I am under the care of an Immunologist for allergies. Don't see him very often as it is something I manage now by myself. My food allergies started with episode of anaphylactic  shock and were diagnosed using skin pricks and blood tests in a NHS allergy clinic (now closed..). My family is allergic and we can react badly and strangely to drugs and chemicals. Given my history the decision by my Oncologist was to start me on the NHS assembly line that they put everyone on, was possibly a bad one. We made a decision to go for chemo as my lump was too big for a lumpectomy. I wasn't prepared to be floored by chemo in the way that I was and by how little educated medical support came my way when I was,  Allergies to drugs in chemo, apart from a straight forward anaphylactic shock reaction, is not accepted by the NHS in my experience. It goes under a heading of "side effects" and then very little is done. They don't accept "intolerances" of drugs or foods as a genuine condition. It may be that your intolerances are not accepted or understood if they do not result in Anaplylatis. Once the drugs are pumped into us we are left to cope with the consequences. There are plenty of lists of side effects available but that's not much help, as in my experience, no one knows what to do once we have them. Even the simple sickness I experienced took months to deal with as i reacted badly to some sickness drugs and doctors shook their heads. There was no pathway for dealing with side effects if they continued and the patient needed care. My GP expected the oncologist to deal with it, my oncologist was out of their depth.  I did better online than I did with all the clinic doctors, nurses and GP's. My Immunologist was some help as well but I had to pay (as no NHS appointments) for this and was too sick to travel to see him. I was also lucky in finding a MacMillian nurse who dealt with palliative care at the local hospice but even that was far too late and too little.  I found that in the Oncology clinic there  was no knowledge of or attempts to understand how food or chemical reactions would affect a patients response to treatment. My previous bad reaction to Dexamethosome and request for this to be changed to Predislone was ignored until I took control and insisted.  I'd be personally less concerned about food allergies in Chemo and more concerned, given my experience, with your bodies reaction to the drugs. My reasoning behind this is that chemo was so severe to me and I had such bad vomiting, sickness and diarrhea that any consideration of existing allergies went completely out the window. Even now, around 4 months after my last big chemo infusion (FEC-T) I am still weak and sick with many other side effects. Some of the drugs used in Chemo (like cyclophosphamide) are being trialed in diseases that have an immune or autoimmune component so if your allergies fit into that area, they may even improve. I'd say that my own food allergies may have improved in some ways but I am still far too sick and weak to work that out fully yet.  Chemo (FEC-T) completely floored me. I was largely housebound for 6 months with occasional trips out for medical appointments in a wheelchair. I had infections on every FEC cycle and eventually refused to be hospitalised.  My liver enzymes were high and I never recovered in the 3 weeks of any cycle and cut the dose of drugs / changed to a 3 week cycle.  The Oncology clinic was not able to deal with such severe multiple side effects. I reacted to the chemo drugs, to the steroids and to the anti-sickness drugs.  They were only geared up to respond to people who had an immediate allergic reaction during the infusion or infections afterwards.  For me antihistamines and Benadryl were the most useful things.  Hydrocortisone and Predislone.  At every step (chemo, surgery and rads) I had allergic reactions to various things like dressing, creams etc. I got sick of dealing with ignorant staff. I don't want to give you the impression that chemo was "all bad", I had chemo to try and shrink a tumour too large for a lumpectomy. It worked really well for me. Hope this ramble helps. We are all different and you could be one of the lucky ones who breezes through. I don't feel as if I have written this very well.

Posts.Content: Hi Suzeanna, I looked into this when faced with a surgeon who wanted to do a full node clearance. Also got other medical conditions plus pre-existing lymphedema already. At the moment the NHS usually offers a node clearance to women who have some proven lymph involvement. However, due to some trials in the USA, it's being questioned in the UK and there is currently a clinical trial here of different approaches to try and answer the question of what to do. http://www.cancerresearchuk.org/about-cancer/find-a-clinical-trial/a-trial-looking-treatment-armpit-breast-cancer-posnoc Sadly, it will be 10 or so years until we have the answer. There are the USA trials though which have been published and are changing the ways women are treated there. What I did was tackle it this way. I needed chemo first anyway to try and shrink the lump so I could have a lumpectomy. It was too large and in the wrong place to operate without reconstruction or mastectomy.  The lymph nodes tested positive on biopsy when I was first diagnosed. The chemo was grueling but a success, the lump shrunk to almost nothing. I decided on a sentinel node biopsy at the same time as the lumpectomy. For me, it worked. There was no cancer in any of the nodes they removed after chemo. I'm recovering from the surgery really well. Touch wood etc. Hope this helps.

I feel that this can be an abusive or oppressive way to treat someone who is suffering. I don't put up with it any longer and I tell people that. Sounds like the people around you either can't cope, are brainwashed into thinking their approach works best or don't want to help you. In all my thinking and feeling I aim to be realistic about any situation I am in. My natural outlook is that of an optimist and I have a great attitude to life. I need however to examine each serious situation I am in and determine the best path for me. This is cancer and this is serious. There is no guarantee of a cure. There is nothing "fine" about having cancer and nothing "fine" about it potentially spreading to your lungs. You need the support of those around you and it sounds as if you are not getting it.
